The article is unclear whether the army sources blame this attack on the FNL.

He was the target of a previous attack (also coded) where an agent of the national intelligence services was wounded, in which the government accused FNL.)

side_b_identity: Emmanuel Minani (nurse and civilian FNL member known as "Papa Lolo") and his 12 year old son, Jospin Nzeyimana. HRW report states that "Minani had been imprisoned for six months in late 2005 at the Documentation Nationale (the precursor to the SNR) and Mpimba prison, accused of FNL membership."
sources: HRW (2009) "Pursuit of Power: Political Violence and Repression in Burundi" p.27
sources_original: HRW interview with LN, family member of the victims.
where: Kinama

side_a_identity: Unidentified armed persons in police uniforms. HRW Report (2009) lists the murders as committed by CNDD-FDD supporters. A neighbour, interviewed by HRW, said that a SNR agent had previously threatened the couple for being FNL supporters, and he recognised this agent's voice as that of the assailant. The neighbour explained that he saw "a man in boots and a police uniform approached the house and demanded that the door be opened, and then fired on the door. When Ngendabanka and Niyonkuru emerged, the man shot and killed them."
side_b: Civilians (suspected to be civilian FNL supporters/members)
side_b_identity: Mr Thimothée Ngendabanka and his wife, Niyonkuru Frédiane (killed) and their baby (injured)

side_a_identity: Unknown (The victim was investogating corruption practices among ruling party officials and it is widely believed his murder was linked to this work. Information from wikipedia: "evidence pointed to the involvement of Burundi Police senior officer Colonel David Nikiza, the head of Burundi intelligence was also suspected according to individuals involved in the political assassination of Ernest Manirumva. His colleagues have alleged that Ernest Manirumva was probably killed as a result of his investigation on Burundi's ruling party CNDD FDD arms trafficking with Khartoum and Rwanda Genocide forces DRC based FDLR" source: Wikipedia)
side_b_identity: Ernest Manirumva, anti-corruption activist
sources: AFP 18/04/2009 "High-profile murder has Burundi activists on edge" / HRW 16/09/2009 "Burundi: Find Killers of Anti-Corruption Activist" / HRW 09/04/2019 "Burundi: 10 Years On, Justice Denied for Murdered Activist" - https://www.hrw.org/news/2019/04/09/burundi-10-years-justice-denied-murdered-activist

sources_original: area's administrator Emile Ndayarinze

side_a_identity: Govt sources blame the opposition. The opposition coalition blame the govt.
side_b_identity: 4 civilians
sources: AFP 13/06/2010 "Grenade attacks in Burundi capital wound seven: police"
sources_original: Police spokesman Pierre Chanel Ntarabaganyi.
where: "near the Saint Michel Church"
geoprecision: 2: within a small radius of an exact location (e.g. “near the town hall”)

side_a_identity: Govt sources blame the opposition. The opposition coalition blame the govt.
side_b_identity: 1 civilian
sources: AFP 13/06/2010 "Grenade attacks in Burundi capital wound seven: police"
sources_original: Police spokesman Pierre Chanel Ntarabaganyi.

side_a_identity: Govt sources blame the opposition. The opposition coalition blame the govt.
side_b_identity: Target: House of local representative of the ruling party (CNDD-FDD) - 2 civilians wounded including a child.
sources: AFP 13/06/2010 "Grenade attacks in Burundi capital wound seven: police"
sources_original: Police spokesman Pierre Chanel Ntarabaganyi.
where: in Cibitoke neighbourhood, at the house of a local representative of the CNDD-FDD

side_a_identity: Police
side_b_identity: FNL militants (supporters) surrounding the house of the FNL leader, Agathon Rwasa
sources: AFP 17/06/2010 "Burundi opposition condemns 'attacks' by police" / AFP 16/06/2010 "Burundi: violences autour du domicile d'un ex-chef rebelle, des blessés"
sources_original: Several sources including Pierre Claver Mbonimpa, President of the Association for the Protection of Prisoners and Human Rights (Aprodeh).
time_original: in the afternoon until late at night
where: Kiriri neighbourhood (one article mentions Mutanga, which borders Kiriri)

side_a_identity: Unknown (climate of political tension where grenade attacks are common - Govt blames opposition for trying to destabilise the peace prior to the elections, opposition blames govt for trying to intimidate opposition parties)
side_b_identity: Unknown (probable civilians)
sources: [Xinhua News Agency 17/06/2010] "Roundup: International community concerned over mounting violence ahead of presidential election in Burundi"
sources_original: Unknown
where: Kamenge

side_a_identity: unidentified armed men
side_b_identity: Head of the Youth League of the CNDD-FDD party in the district of Gisyo de la Kanyosha commune.
sources: Le Service en français de Xinhua, 20/06/2010 "Burundi: un militant du parti au pouvoir tué par des hommes armés en mairie de Bujumbura" / AFP 22/06/2010 "Burundi: trois morts dans de nouvelles violences et attaques à la grenade"
sources_original: administrator of Kanyosha commune, Abraham Aoudou Bampoye
where: "near his home in Kanyosha"

side_a_identity: Governemnt accuses opposition of causing instability prior to elections but opposition blames government for creating climate of insecurity and intimidation for opposition parties.

sources: AFP 22/06/2010 "Burundi: trois morts dans de nouvelles violences et attaques à la grenade" / AFP 22/06/2010 "Three killed in Burundi violence"

side_a_identity: National Intelligence Service (Service National de Reseignement, SNR)
side_b_identity: Members of opposition parties such as FNL and MSD
sources: AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL Report, August 23 2010 - “A Step Backwards” – Torture and other Ill-Treatment by Burundi’s National Intelligence Service
sources_original: Detainees interviewed by Amnesty International. Amnesty International also interviewed individuals who had witnessed key incidents of political violence, and representatives of local and international non-governmental organizations, journalists, diplomats and the United Nations for this report.
where: In the SNR headquarters in Bujumbura

side_a_identity: National Intelligence Service (Service National de Reseignement, SNR)
side_b_identity: FNL member
sources: Human Rights Watch (2010) "Closing Doors? The Narrowing of Democratic Space in Burundi."
sources_original: HRW interviewed detainee
where: In the SNR headquarters in Bujumbura

side_a_identity: Governemnt accuses opposition of targetting CNDD-FDD members ahead of elections (but opposition denies this and blames Govt for creating insecurity ahead of elections)
side_b_identity: Local representative of the ruling party (CNDD-FDD) - his son was wounded
sources: AFP 25/06/2010 "Burundi: une personne tuée et deux blessées dans de nouvelles violences"
sources_original: Police spokesperson: major Pierre Chanel Ntarabaganyi.
where: Nyakabiga (at the home of a local CNDD-FDD representative)

side_a_identity: Unknown (climate of political tension where grenade attacks are common - Govt blames opposition for trying to destabilise the peace prior to the elections, opposition blames govt for trying to intimidate opposition parties. In this case, since FNL is targetted, possibility of attack being perpetrated by CNDD-FDD)
side_b_identity: Local official with the National Liberation Forces (FNL)

sources_original: Police chief Pierre Chanel Ntarabaganyi

where: Kanyosha

side_a_identity: Unknown
side_b_identity: "a man" - possible civilian but unknown

sources_original: local administrator Désiré Simbizi
time_original: "in the night between Friday and Saturday"

side_a_identity: Unknown (Government accuses opposition)
side_b_identity: Unknown

time_original: "in the night between Monday and Tuesday"

side_a_identity: National Intelligence Service (Service National de Reseignement, SNR)
side_b_identity: 2 MSD members
sources: Human Rights Watch (2010) "Closing Doors? The Narrowing of Democratic Space in Burundi."
sources_original: HRW interviewed detainees

side_a_identity: Unknown (authorities later arrested FNL members and charegd them with complicity of murder despite lack of evidence)
side_b_identity: "men believed to be CNDD-FDD members"
sources: Human Rights Watch (2010) "Closing Doors? The Narrowing of Democratic Space in Burundi."
sources_original: Human Rights Watch interviews with victims’ neighbors and family members, Kanyosha, July 15, 2010
where: In Ruziba, a neighbourhood in Kanyosha

side_a_identity: National Intelligence Service (Service National de Reseignement, SNR)
side_b_identity: The specific case does not mention any identity, however it appears in a section of the HRW report that explains torture of opposition members and political activists.
sources: Human Rights Watch (2010) "Closing Doors? The Narrowing of Democratic Space in Burundi."
sources_original: Charles Petrie, BINUB Executive Representative of the Secretary General
where: In the SNR headquarters in Bujumbura

side_a_identity: Armed men in military uniform (could be FNL members: the administrator of the commune of Kanyosha claims the attack could be settling of scores between FNL and CNDD-FDD)
side_b_identity: Police
sources: AFP 23/10/2010 "Burundi: un policier blessé au cours d'une attaque"
sources_original: Evariste Ndabakeneye,  administrator of Kanyosha commune
where: Kanyosha

side_a_identity: "Armed bandits" (could be FNL members: the target of the attack was the home of the head of national intelligence services, General Adolphe Nshimirimana, "pillar of the Nkurunziza regime")
side_b_identity: General Adolphe Nshimirimana, head of national intelligence services, linked to the Nkurunziza regime
sources: AFP 26/10/2010 "Burundi: huit morts dans des affrontements entre "bandits" et soldats" / AFP 26/10/2010 "Eight die in Burundi clashes"
sources_original: General David Nikiza, Commissioner General of the West Police Region
where: In Mugoboke, at the home of the head of the Burundian secret services in Bujumbura

side_a_identity: Unidentified armed men (threats found in his office by CNDD-FDD members telling him to join their party imply they might be involved in his killing)
side_b_identity: Jean-Bosco Bugingo, chef de zone (local official) and member of FRODEBU
sources: HRW (2012) “You Will Not Have Peace While You Are Living”. The Escalation of Political Violence in Burundi. P.37
sources_original: HRW interviews with people close to the victim.
where: "in his compound in Ruziba, Bujumbura Mairie" (error here, I think Ruziba is in Bujumbura rural but within our coding perimeter)

side_a_identity: Unknown (Spokesperson of UPD party claims victim was targetted for his political stance and killed by people against his militantism for the UPD party. Could be group linked to the ruling CNDD-FDD party). HRW states that the victim has been pressured by CNDD-FDD into joining their movement but he refused, implying they could have wanted him dead.
side_b_identity: Cheikh Hamza Congera, imam and activist member of the UPD party
sources: AFP 9/12/2010 "Burundi: un imam et opposant politique assassiné en pleine rue"
sources_original: various sources including Chauvineau Mugwengezo, spokesperson of the UPD party
where: near his mosque in Buyenzi

side_a_identity: Unidentified armed men - suspected FNL members (family members reported that victim and themselved had been threatened by FNL members)
side_b_identity: Désiré Hakizimana, fish trader and member of CNDD-FDD
sources: HRW (2012) “You Will Not Have Peace While You Are Living”. The Escalation of Political Violence in Burundi. P.44
sources_original: HRW interviews with people close to the victim.
where: at his home, in Bujumbura town

side_a_identity: Unknown (grenade placement in street among scraps of metal suggests aim to cause indiscriminate damage which could imply political violence. Article mentions Somali Shebab gorup and political instabiity in Burundi could be behind attacks).
side_b_identity: Civilians (3 killed, 3 injured)
sources: AFP 01/01/2011 "Burundi grenade blast kills three"
sources_original: Army spokesman Colonel Gaspard Baratuza
where: in the Buyenzi neighbourhood

side_a_identity: Army
side_b_identity: "gang of criminals" (context of rumours of armed rebellion starting up again, and article implies the neighbourhood where the killings happened had seen pamphlets to advocate for a rebellion).
sources: Le Service en français de Xinhua, 05/02/2011 "Quatre personnes tuées par l'armée en pleine journée dans la capitale burundaise"
sources_original: Colonel Gaspard Baratuza, army spokesman
where: Gihosha

side_a_identity: More than 50 armed men in military and police unifiorms. Police call them "armed bandits" but Human Right groups are accusing the government of extra-judicial killings of FNL members and other opposition party members and covering the killings up with the "armed bandits" discourse.
side_b_identity: Police
sources: Xinhua News Agency 14/02/2011 "Gunmen attack police post in Burundi's capital Bujumbura"
sources_original: witnesses and the administrator of Kanyosha, Abraham Aoudou Bampoye
where: Ruziba in the community of Kanyosha (note: Kanyosha can refer to an area of Bujumbura Rural in the east, or a neighbourhood of Bujumbura Mairie in the south. We will use Ruziba located in the latter to code this event)

side_a_identity: Suspected Imbonerakure (Pro-Govt): neighbours state they saw members of the Imbonerauke follow the victim home the evening of his death.
side_b_identity: Pasteur Mpaganje (aka "Giswi"), FNL member in Ruziba local community
sources: HRW (2012) “You Will Not Have Peace While You Are Living”. The Escalation of Political Violence in Burundi. P.32
sources_original: HRW interviews with persons close to the victim and letter from V. Bagorikunda, prosecutor General
where: at his home in Ruziba, Bujumbura

side_a_identity: Cyrille Nahimana (SNR agent) + 3 police officers
side_b_identity: Audace Vianney Habonarugira, former (demobilized) FNL commander
sources: HRW (2012) “You Will Not Have Peace While You Are Living”. The Escalation of Political Violence in Burundi. P.22
sources_original: The victim, A. Habonarugira, interviewed by HRW as well as other interviews with relatives and friends of victim.
where: "a 100 meters from my house" in Kamenge

side_a_identity: FNL (party) (article strongly implies)
side_b_identity: 3 members of the CNDD-FDD
sources: AFP 15/04/2011 "Three killed in Burundi unrest"
sources_original: Unknown
where: Ruziba in the community of Kanyosha (note: Kanyosha can refer to an area of Bujumbura Rural in the east, or a neighbourhood of Bujumbura Mairie in the south. We will use Ruziba located in the latter to code this event)

side_a_identity: Locals, witnesses and family blame the secret services (govt); a local official said the attack was carried out by "armed bandits", a term routinely employed by the government to explain the wave of killings.
side_b_identity: Innocent Ngendakuriyo and his 20-year-old son, who were FNL party members.
sources: AFP 15/04/2011 "Three killed in Burundi unrest"
sources_original: witnesses, a family member and a local official
where: On the outskirts of the capital Bujumbura

side_a_identity: Locals blame the police and a group of ruling party youth (Imbonerakure); Police blame "armed bandits"
side_b_identity: 4 civilians wounded
sources: AFP 15/04/2011 "Three killed in Burundi unrest"
sources_original: locals and police spokesman Pierre Chanel Ntarabaganyi
where: In Ruziba area

side_a_identity: Family blames Imbonerakure
side_b_identity: Wilson Ndayishimiye, 4 year old boy, son of two FNL members.
sources: HRW (2012) “You Will Not Have Peace While You Are Living”. The Escalation of Political Violence in Burundi. P.33
sources_original: HRW interviews with persons close to victim.
where: at his house in Ruziba, Bujumbura

side_a_identity: Unknown (Govt has accused FNL Rwasa faction of being behind political violence that is frequent this year)
side_b_identity: CNDD-FDD and Imbonerakure (Target was a bar where Imbonerakure and CNDD-FDD members often hang out.)
sources: AFP 17 May 2011 "Burundi: une grenade jetée dans un bar à Bujumbura, un mort et neuf blessés"
sources_original: Witnesses, local administrator Abraham Bampoye, anonymous police officer.
where: In a bar in Kanyosha, a southern neighbourhood of Bujumbura (indicating this is the Kanyosha included in Bujumbura Mairie)

side_a_identity: A dozen men in military uniform - "armed bandits" - suspected FNL (Govt has accused FNL Rwasa faction of being behind political violence that is frequent this year. Witnesses claim the attackers were singing FNL combat songs)
side_b_identity: CNDD-FDD party members (target was a bar where CNDD-FDD members often hang out)
sources: AFP 29/05/2011 "Burundi: 4 civils tués dans une attaque en périphérie de Bujumbura" / AllAfrica 6/06/2011 "4 civils tués au fief d'un parlementaire" / HRW (2012) “You Will Not Have Peace While You Are Living”. The Escalation of Political Violence in Burundi. P.46
sources_original: Local administrator of Kanyosha commune, Abdul Bampoye
where:
in a restaurant in the neighborhoods of Nkenga and Busoro of the urban commune of Kanyosha
HRW report states "a bar in Bisoro" - cannot find either Busoro or Bisoro.

side_a_identity: unidentified armed group in police uniforms (context suggests renewal of violence from FNL faction. In other articles in the same period, government sources accuse FNL of attacks of this kind).
side_b_identity: Army position
sources: AFP 22/06/2011 "Burundi: au moins cinq morts dans trois attaques distinctes"
sources_original: witnesses and a local administrative official, Richard Nininahazwe
where: In the Musaga neighbourhood, about 2km from Bujumbura city centre

side_a_identity: Police officers and men in military uniforms (since the victim had already been targetted by Cyrille Nahimana (SNR agent) and the police, it is reasonable to assume the perpetrators are the same than in case BUJ11030701-00)
side_b_identity: Audace Vianney Habonarugira, former (demobilized) FNL commander and Claude Kwizera, believed to be a demobilized FNL combatant and friend of Habonarugira
sources: HRW (2012) “You Will Not Have Peace While You Are Living”. The Escalation of Political Violence in Burundi. P.24
sources_original: HRW interviews with persons close to victim
where: Abducted from Bujumbura (where they were in hiding) and taken to Gasamanzuki in Isare commune (Bujumbura Rural) to be killed

side_a_identity: Police
side_b_identity: unidentified "armed bandits" hiding in a house supposedly owned by an ex-FNL combattant. Witnesses claim the victims killed were FNL combattants but the police say they were "armed bandits".
sources: AFP 7/07/2011 "Burundi: trois "bandits armés" tués dans un quartier du sud de la capitale"
sources_original: Local administrator of Kanyosha commune, Abdul Bampoye
where: "in a houe in the Ruziba zone" of Kanyosha

side_a_identity: Police
side_b_identity: Suspected FNL: Govt sources claim the "armed bandits" were FNL members of the Rwasa faction starting a new rebellion. One of the victims was said to be an ex police officer who later joined the FNL (Edouard Ruvayanga)
sources: Reuters News 06/09/2011 "Burundi police kill two in shootout in capital" / AFP 06/09/2011 "Burundi : deux "bandits armés" tués dans une fusillade avec la police à Bujumbura"
sources_original: Police spokesperson: major Pierre Chanel Ntarabaganyi.
where: In the Kinindo neighbourhood

side_a_identity: Police
side_b_identity: Mostly Tutsi civilians from Nagara neighbourhood, protesting the expulsion of a Tutsi family from a house originally owned by a Hutu victim of the 1972 genocide.
sources: AFP 28/05/2013 "Burundi: scènes d'émeutes à Bujumbura lors d'une restitution liée aux massacres de 1972" / AFP 7/06/2013 "Burundi, a nation divided over land" / AllAfrica 29/05/2013 "Les conflits fonciers provoquent des émeutes sur fond de tensions ethniques"
sources_original: A spokesperon of the Tutsi youth, CNTB president Pierre-Claver Sinzinkayo, police sources
time_original: started in the morning, police action started around midday [AllAfrica 29/05/2013]
where: Ngagara

side_a_identity: Police
side_b_identity: UPRONA party members (civilians) outside the headquarters of the party (UPRONA which had been part of the presidential coalition withdrew support for P. Nkurunzuzia and CNDD-FDD causing political and ethnic tensions)
sources: Reuters, 16/02/2014 "Burundi police try to stop party meeting as crisis deepens - witnesses"  / AFP, 16/02/2014 "La police disperse un rassemblement d'opposants tutsi au Burundi"
sources_original: witnesses; Burundi's interior minister Edouard Nduwimana; UPRONA deputy chairman Evariste Ngayimpenda
where: At the headquarters of the UPRONA party in Bujumbura

side_a_identity: Police
side_b: MSD (party) - Mouvement pour la Solidarité et la Démocratie
side_b_identity: MSD party members
sources: Reuters 09/03/2014 "Burundi police clash with opposition members, 15 injured" / AllAfrica, 10/03/2014 "Violents affrontements entre policiers et opposants" / AFP 12/03/2014 "Burundi: un chef de l'opposition et 71 militants inculpés d'"insurrection"
sources_original: witnesses, police spokesman Hermenegilde Harimenshi
time_original: "late on Saturday" (but seems events lasted several hours, and started with a "collective run" in the afternoon.
where: At the headquarters of the MSD party in Bujumbura

side_a_identity: unidentified armed men
side_b_identity: Gaston Sindimwo, general secretary of UPRONA party
sources: Le Service en français de Xinhua, 17/03/2014, "Burundi : attaque à la grenade contre la résidence d'un homme politique" / more info at: ZEGABI 18/03/2014 - https://www.zegabi.com/articles/7856
sources_original: "popular sources"
where: "At M. Gaston Sindimwo's residence in Bujumbura" (found online that he lived in Nyakabiga)

side_a_identity: Unknown
side_b_identity: Gaston Sindimwo, general secretary of UPRONA party
sources: Agence Bujumbura News, 17/05/2014 - https://bujanews.wordpress.com/2014/05/17/attaque-a-la-grenade-au-domicile-de-gaston-sindimwo/ / Isanganiro, 18/05/2014 - https://isanganiro.org/2014/05/18/encore-une-attaque-a-la-grenade-chez-gaston-sindimwo/
sources_original: Unknown / a female neighbour
where: At M. Gaston Sindimwo's residence in Bujumbura, in Nyakabiga Commune

side_a_identity: Unknown (authorities claim violence is caused by armed bandits, and common criminals, however in the weeks and months surrounding this attack, other similar attacks have been reported in the Bujumbura Rural province (oustide of the scope of our coding) where armed men dressed in "long black coats" as described by witnesses, seem to be part of a newly formed rebel group. Furthermore, opposition members and civil society representatives have accused the Imbonerakure of being behind these attacks (claims mentioned in other articles).
side_b_identity: 2 civilian men
sources: BBC Monitoribng Africa (taken from RFI), 10/11/2014 "Unknown armed gangs launching machete attacks in Burundi"
sources_original: Esdras Ndikumana, RFI
where: "in Musaga, hardly three km south of the Central Business District."
